options.label: B

options.text: Alport's syndrome is the likely diagnosis

questions.correct_answer: A. No IgG deposits or C3 deposition on renal biopsy

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents with pelvic pain and is found to have an ovarian mass of the left ovary that measures 3 cm in diameter. Grossly, the mass consists of multiple cystic spaces. Histologically, these cysts are lined by tall columnar epithelium, with some of the cells being ciliated. What is your diagnosis of this ovarian tumor, which histologically recapitulates the histology of the fallopian tubes?

A 5-year-old girl is brought to your office by her mother, who states that the girl has been drinking a lot of water lately. Physical examination reveals a young girl whose eyes protrude slightly. Further workup reveals the presence of multiple lytic bone lesions involving her calvarium and the base of her skull. What is the most likely diagnosis for this young girl?

A 55 year old post menopausal women complains of recent onset diarrhoea, fatigue and tiredness. Her evaluation reveals anemia, with low MCV and low MCHC. Platelet count and total leucocyte count are within normal limits. Family history reveals death of an aunt due to endometrial cancer at an early age. Stool is positive for occult blood. Colonoscopy revealed a 5 cm large cauliflower like growth in the ascending colon. A panel for mutation analysis is being discussed by her treating surgeon and pathologist. Which mutation if present will not alter the course of management for the patient?

A 29 year old male patient presents with bleeding gums, fatigue, petechial rashes and recurrent infections. Physical examination shows splenomegaly. Laboratory evaluation reveals an increased total leucocyte count, low Hb and low platelet count. Differential count shows 65% atypical looking cells with hypergranular cytoplasm and multiple Auer rods. Coagulation profile shows raised Prothrombin time and Activated partial thromboplastin time. Increased fibrinogen degradation products especially D-dimers are found as well. Which of the following drug combinations is best recommended for this patient?

A 65 year old male patient complains of on and off fever, long standing fatigue and dragging sensation on left side of the abdomen. Physical examination shows pallor and splenomegaly. CBC evaluation shows anemia, normal platelet count, and raised TLC. DLC count shows left shift in myeloid cells, basophilia and eosinophilia. A panel of investigations are being planned. Which of the following will not help in distinguishing between an infection and a myeloid malignancy in this patient?

A 49 year old male patient hailing from a hilly area presents with fever and splenomegaly. He also complains of fatigue and frequent headaches with blurring of vision. On CBC evaluation, Hb is 16.8 g/dL, TLC is high with left shift in myeloid series. Platelet count is normal. The next investigation in management of this patient should be

options.label: B
options.text: Bone marrow biopsy stained with reticulin stain

questions.text: A 64 year old male patient with lower back pain, extreme fatigue and heaviness in left hypochondrium is under evaluation. Serology shows raised levels of PSA. CBC shows low Hb, low platelet count and low TLC. Peripheral smear shows the following. Which of the following special stains will help to clinch the diagnosis?

A 16 years old male patient presents with fever and shortness of breath since a week along with easy bruisability and fatigue. He complains that when he wakes up in the morning, his face is very swollen but the swelling subsides as the day progresses. Hepatosplenomegaly is also evident. CBC shows raised TLC with DLC showing atypical large cells with scanty agranular cytoplasm. Which of the following CD marker on flow cytometry will confirm the nature of the atypical cells?

An 8 year old male patient presents with intussusception of small bowel. A mass lesion measuring 4.6 cm is identified and biopsied. The following is the histopathology of the lesion. Genetic analysis showed t(8;22). Which gene is expected to be the driving force behind the causation of the lesion?

A 58 year old female patient presented with anemia, bone pain, fever and cough. Chest X ray shows pulmonary infiltrates and the skull X ray is shown below. Peripheral blood smear is also shown below. Serum electrophoresis shows 36 g/L of M protein and urine shows 4+ proteinuria. Calcium levels and serum creatinine levels are raised. Bone marrow aspirate shows clusters of cells with basophilic cytoplasm, perinuclear halo and eccentric nuclei. Some multinucleated cells as well as intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions containing cells are also seen. Which of the following CD markers are expected to be positive in these cells?

A 42 year old woman presents with epigastric pain, sensation of abdominal pressure and unintentional weight loss. Physical examination reveals hyperpigmented patches on her neck and enlarged supraclavicular lymph nodes. Endoscopy does not reveal a mucosal mass however the gastric wall appears thickened. A biopsy was taken and sent for histopathology, picture of which is shown below. Which gene is most likely expected to be mutated in this lesion?

A 48 year old man with history of GERD presents with complaints dysphagia, heartburn and difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids. Endoscopy shows a mass in the lower esophagus, which is biopsied. An old histopathology report makes the pathologist confident of the expected histopathology finding in the sample received. The old histopathology picture of the slide stained with Alcian Blue is shown below. What will be seen in the sample received by the pathologist now?

options.label: B
options.text: Cells with mucin inside pushing nuclei

questions.text: A 13 year old female patient presented to the emergency with acute diffuse abdominal pain for the past 12 hours. Her temperature was 37.7 deg C, with slightly raised blood pressure and physical examination shows abdominal distension with tenderness on palpation. A tense sausage shaped mass is felt in the upper abdomen. Gums and lips show dark spots. Further investigations reveal multiple sessile and pedunculated polyps in the GI tract. A biopsy performed showed a characteristic histopathological appearance prompting analysis of a gene mutation, thus confirming the diagnosis. The family was then counselled about risk of breast and pancreatic cancer in the family, and screening of other members as well. Which gene mutation was found?

A 10 years old male patient presents with pain near the knee, with a growing mass which on X ray appeared as follows. The diagnosis of a malignant bone tumour was made. The patient has history presenting with a white reflex in left eye at the age of 1.5 years, which turned out to be an early form of a tumour and was treated with radiation. A clinician suspects a familial cancer and decides to test for a gene, which turned out to be mutated, thus confirming his suspicion. This gene works as a

options.label: D
options.text: Inhibitor of cell cycle at G1-S

questions.correct_answer: D. Inhibitor of cell cycle at G1-S

questions.text: A 42 years old woman admitted in your ward has recently been diagnosed with Her 2 neu positive breast cancer. As a new resident, you are encouraged to talk to the patients and obtain a full history for case presentation. While questioning the patient, you find out that this is not her first admission for cancer treatment. As a child, she was diagnosed with an acute leukemia and osteosarcoma as well. Her sister died of glioblastoma only 2 years back. While your colleagues think of it as bad luck running in the family, you begin to worry about inherited cancer syndromes. Which gene mutation if inherited best explains this syndrome your patient has?

A 58 years old male smoker presents with haemoptysis, muscle weakness, nausea, headache and confusion. Further investigations reveal an electrolyte abnormality. Urine osmolality is greater than 100 mOsm/kg. CT shows a central hilar mass which is biopsied and shows small cells with high N:C ratio, stippled chromatin and crush artefact on histopathology. options.text: Best prognosis among all lung cancers

questions.correct_answer: C. Best prognosis among all lung cancers

questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that results in destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual and progressive thyroid failure. It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in areas of the world where iodine levels are sufficient. The name is derived from the 1912 report by Hashimoto describing patients with goiter and intense lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid (strumalymphomatosa). It is most prevalent between 45 and 65 years of age and is more common in women than in men, with a female predominance of 10 : 1 to 20 : 1. It can also occur in children and is a major cause of nonendemic goiter in the pediatric population. There is relentless destruction of thyroid follicles over the years, with eventual atrophy, so that the thyroid is often not palpable when a patient presents with myxedema from hypothyroidism, and the serum TSH is elevated. Hashimoto thyroiditis most often comes to clinical attention as painless enlargement of the thyroid, usually associated with some degree of hypothyroidism, in a middle-aged woman. The enlargement of the gland is usually symmetric and diffuse, but in some cases it may be sufficiently localized to raise the suspicion of a neoplasm Early in the course of this disease, there may be transient hyperthyroidism from excessive release of thyroid hormones from damaged follicles. Other autoimmune diseases, such as Addison disease or pernicious anemia, may also occur in patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis. There is an increased risk for subsequent development of B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • ↳ Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that results in destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual and progressive thyroid failure.
  • ↳ It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in areas of the world where iodine levels are sufficient.
  • ↳ The name is derived from the 1912 report by Hashimoto describing patients with goiter and intense lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid (strumalymphomatosa).
  • ↳ It is most prevalent between 45 and 65 years of age and is more common in women than in men, with a female predominance of 10 : 1 to 20 : 1.
  • ↳ It can also occur in children and is a major cause of nonendemic goiter in the pediatric population.
  • ↳ There is relentless destruction of thyroid follicles over the years, with eventual atrophy, so that the thyroid is often not palpable when a patient presents with myxedema from hypothyroidism, and the serum TSH is elevated.
  • ↳ Hashimoto thyroiditis most often comes to clinical attention as painless enlargement of the thyroid, usually associated with some degree of hypothyroidism, in a middle-aged woman.
  • ↳ The enlargement of the gland is usually symmetric and diffuse, but in some cases it may be sufficiently localized to raise the suspicion of a neoplasm
  • ↳ Early in the course of this disease, there may be transient hyperthyroidism from excessive release of thyroid hormones from damaged follicles.
  • ↳ Other autoimmune diseases, such as Addison disease or pernicious anemia, may also occur in patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis.
  • ↳ There is an increased risk for subsequent development of B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma

questions.text: Following FISH analysis (red= 22q, green= 22p) shows a certain condition. Which of the following is not true about it?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Chromosome 22q11.2 deletion syndrome encompasses a spectrum of disorders that result from a small deletion of band q11.2 on the long arm of chromosome 22. The syndrome is fairly common, occurring in as many as 1 in 4000 births, but it is often missed because of variable clinical features. These include congenital heart defects, abnormalities of the palate, facial dysmorphism, developmental delay, and variable degrees of T-cell immunodeficiency and hypocalcemia. Previously, these clinical features were considered to represent two different disorders—DiGeorge syndrome and velocardiofacial syndrome. Patients with DiGeorge syndrome have thymic hypoplasia, with resultant T-cell immunodeficiency , parathyroid hypoplasia giving rise to hypocalcemia, a variety of cardiac malformations affecting the outflow tract, and mild facial anomalies. The clinical features of the so-called velocardiofacial syndrome include facial dysmorphism (prominent nose, retrognathia), cleft palate, cardiovascular anomalies, and learning disabilities. Less frequently, these patients also have immunodeficiency. Until recently the overlapping clinical features of these two conditions (e.g., cardiac malformations, facial dysmorphology) were not appreciated; it was only after these two apparently unrelated syndromes were found to be associated with a similar cytogenetic abnormality that the clinical overlap came into focus. Recent studies indicate that, in addition to the numerous structural malformations, individuals with the 22q11.2 deletion syndrome are at a particularly high risk for psychotic illnesses, such as schizophrenia and bipolar disorders. In fact, it is estimated that schizophrenia develops in approximately 25% of adults with this syndrome. Conversely, deletions of the region can be found in 2% to 3% of individuals with childhood-onset schizophrenia. In addition, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder is seen in 30% to 35% of affected children
  • ↳ Chromosome 22q11.2 deletion syndrome encompasses a spectrum of disorders that result from a small deletion of band q11.2 on the long arm of chromosome 22.
  • ↳ The syndrome is fairly common, occurring in as many as 1 in 4000 births, but it is often missed because of variable clinical features.
  • ↳ These include congenital heart defects, abnormalities of the palate, facial dysmorphism, developmental delay, and variable degrees of T-cell immunodeficiency and hypocalcemia.
  • ↳ Previously, these clinical features were considered to represent two different disorders—DiGeorge syndrome and velocardiofacial syndrome.
  • ↳ Patients with DiGeorge syndrome have thymic hypoplasia, with resultant T-cell immunodeficiency , parathyroid hypoplasia giving rise to hypocalcemia, a variety of cardiac malformations affecting the outflow tract, and mild facial anomalies.
  • ↳ The clinical features of the so-called velocardiofacial syndrome include facial dysmorphism (prominent nose, retrognathia), cleft palate, cardiovascular anomalies, and learning disabilities.
  • ↳ Less frequently, these patients also have immunodeficiency.
  • ↳ Until recently the overlapping clinical features of these two conditions (e.g., cardiac malformations, facial dysmorphology) were not appreciated; it was only after these two apparently unrelated syndromes were found to be associated with a similar cytogenetic abnormality that the clinical overlap came into focus.
  • ↳ Recent studies indicate that, in addition to the numerous structural malformations, individuals with the 22q11.2 deletion syndrome are at a particularly high risk for psychotic illnesses, such as schizophrenia and bipolar disorders.
  • ↳ In fact, it is estimated that schizophrenia develops in approximately 25% of adults with this syndrome.
  • ↳ Conversely, deletions of the region can be found in 2% to 3% of individuals with childhood-onset schizophrenia.
  • ↳ In addition, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder is seen in 30% to 35% of affected children
